You're a dead rabbit, who's also the prince of Hell, who's primary mode of transportation is a buzzsaw with an assortment of guns attached to it. That says plenty, right there.

That said, if the silliness of the game doesn't interest you, then it's not for you, as the gameplay is less than stellar. The platforming and shooting is mediocre at best, and frustrating at worst. If you're interested in this game, I'd honestly reccommend watching a playthrough rather than playing it yourself, as you'd probably have more fun that way.

The personality IS pretty great, though, not going to lie. Hell, if it does well enough, maybe we can see a sequel with enough of a budget to improve on the actual gameplay and be a truely radical game. MAYBE ONE DAY.

reviewText:
Remember when platformers weren't all trying to be arty metaphors for life, loss and all that other fancy crap? If you find a metaphor in Hell Yeah's relentless assault on your eyes and sanity, it's only because it's about to get dropkicked by an angry demon rabbit riding a giant spinning death blade with a jetpack on the back.

This is one of those games where the design process didn't involve whiteboards and long discussions, but some chemist's secret stash being ground up and dripped into the artists' eyeballs. You're Ash, disgraced rabbit prince of Hell, on a quest to kill 100 wacky monsters who saw paparazzi photos of you playing with a rubber duckie in the bath. That's as sane as Hell Yeah! ever gets. It's a game where firing shark missiles is all in a day's work.

Hell Yeah review Hell Yeah's drillable rocks look delicious. You'd eat that at the funfair.
Getting to your enemies is relatively standard platform fare, with the twist that you can often drill through obstacles, boost jump around the place, and acquire different weapons. Actually killing your foes, however, involves playing Warioware-style microgames such as stealing honey from a suspicious bee to unleash an appropriate fatality move, which might be having a dinosaur bite their head off for you.

It's the chaos of Earthworm Jim in the levels of Sonic the Hedgehog 2, with a little Ren and Stimpy/Invader Zim (delete according to age) thrown in for good measure. Gags and minigames repeat more than they should, but still survive the repetition of gags and minigames repeating more than they should, which both gags and minigames do.

The action itself, while enjoyable, soon lets things down. While Hell Yeah! is a fantastic looking game, it's one that paid more attention to looking good than playing great. There's so much going on most of the time that it's often hard to take in and get a proper read on the levels and what's going to hurt if you run straight into it.

More routinely irritating are the controls, where double-jumps, skids and simply being knocked back by enemies will often frustrate you. You want an Xbox 360 controller for this one. You could play it with a keyboard, but only in the same sense that technically you could fly if you flapped your arms hard enough. Either way, prepare for unhelpful checkpoints, and the irritations of repeated cutscenes and similar hold-ups soon being promoted to fully-fledged annoyances. They take the shine off the chaos rather than the fun out of it, however, and you soon return to the forward momentum Hell Yeah! needs.

The game's obvious enthusiasm carries it over these bumps in the road, and if you can forgive, you can easily forget in the race for the next bit of insanity. Hell Yeah! is no platforming classic, but it's cheap enough to be worth a punt if you like the idea of its craziness, and crazy enough to get your money's worth long before the end.

THE VERDICT
72/100

reviewText:
Hell Yeah! is an action-platformer where your goal is to slay the 100 monsters that saw your embarassing photos. Ash, the Prince of Hell, definitely wants to protect his image. The game packs plenty of jokes and copious amounts of blood. It's also built like a metroidvania, but at the same time, doesn't feel like one.

Also, there are a number of problems with this game that interfere heavily with the fun experience of slaying and collecting monsters. Let's start with those problems first before going into what the game does right.

The Issues
The game resolution seems to be 720p and is upscaled to any higher resolutions. This gives it a blurry look which is unpleasant. I was able to look past it because the gameplay kept me engaged until the other problems revealed their final form.
There is a slight momentum to Ash's movement which causes the game to feel clumsy. This can result in unintended falls if landing on the edge of a platform or slipping since angled surfaces cause Ash to automatically slide down.
The wall jump in this game is Hold A and bounce off the walls type of deal. This kind of button assignment creates a frustrating number of incidents that result in bouncing backwards when you're just trying to platform normally with the double jump where if you hold A for each jump, you gain more height.
There are some trial and error sections and blind jumps with the latter being rare.
When you die, any conversations or camera pan movements that highlight an area of the map are reset and play again. And again. With each and every death. This is one of the most annoying things about the game.
The checkpoints are not the greatest.
Monster slaying minigames can kill you if you're not quick enough to figure out the gimmick. Most of them are ok. Others are annoying.
Very barebones options menu.
I didn't like the sections where weapons are taken away as much, especially since you lose the rocket (wheel) jump and have to deal with the wall jump.
Aiming can be difficult and when jumping around at the same time.
You don't explore for hidden items. It's mostly a finding cash type of deal to spend in shops.
Hell Yeah! has good points too. I liked the silly customization. The humor seemed fine to me. I liked the monster descriptions. Drilling through things felt pretty good. The visual style looks good. Some of the monster slaying mini-games are fun or over-the-top (some of them are repeated). It has a weird management meta-game. Finally, the action portion seemed just fine and the weapon variety is there to support it.

I can only recommend this game to people that have more patience than me for trial and error. Based on my experience, I have to give it a thumbs down, which is a shame since I enjoyed most of my time with the game, but lost any desire to continue. For reference, I slayed 60 out of 100 monsters.

Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit may look like an engaging platformer at first glance because of its cartoony art style and a promise of a crazy, adrenaline-fueled adventure but the actual product gives its players nothing more than a mediocre experience and unchallenging gameplay. Granted, the game starts off strong and sets its comedic tone in a mature yet quirky fashion but it quickly goes downhill once the lack of difficulty becomes apparent and the looming repetitiveness sets in. I'm still giving this a recommended even though I didn't enjoy it that much because I can see the potential and it's hard not to see its appeal over a select audience. If it works out its kinks in a future update, I may change my opinion about it.

Has a mature yet comedic tone though some jokes fall flat and may make one cringe, especially the pop culture and self-referential humor.
Appealing art direction. What you see in the store page is what you get in the game: a cartoony version of hell that's oozing with style and gore.
Metroidvania-style gameplay albeit at a much relaxed pace and with simpler mechanics. Too bad that the level design is so-so for a platformer and exploration doesn't yield rewards.
Controls quickly change according to what peripheral you're using at the moment and can be rebinded. Also, KB+M can be used in the menus and UIs which is a really nice touch considering that most AAA ports don't do this stuff. The problem with the controls - which many players are experiencing - is that there's some sort of extra momentum with every action, making everything feel slippery.
PC-exclusive options are very limited. Graphics options only consists of resolution and fullscreen toggle. Volume sliders are nowhere to be seen.
I haven't experienced any crashes whatsoever but the game has a bug where it mutes the music indefinitely when alt+tabing for too long.
Amazing soundtrack.


And there you have it.

Hell Yeah isn't great, but it isn't terrible either. It's a mix of both. Let me explain:
The humor is hit and miss - at times it's genuinely funny, at times it's extremely childish. You could say it's for both kids and adults, but in my opinion that's nonsense and it just isn't consistent.

It performs well in the killing aspect, especially the finishing (mini-game) moves, and not too bad in the platforming aspect, but the controls take some time getting used to and the platforming is at times very imprecise, which results in you falling off ledges regularly.
And I really disliked the backtracking, even if it's for short distances. This is no Metroidvania game. Backtracking in this game is an artificial way to extend the game and it's highly unneccesary if you ask me. It is already packed with content so there's plenty of other stuff to do.

reviewText:
Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit is I guess an action platformer with puzzle elements.

Its an enjoyable experience clocking in at around 4-6 hours depending on whether you go for 100% of the achievements. Its a very easy game to perfect, so if you're looking to improve your completion rate and its in your library play it.

The graphics are cartoonish. yet work well with the game and atmosphere. Hell Yeah! is split up into different worlds, all as colourful and imaginitive as the next. Your objective is to kill the monsters(mini bosses) in place, there are also main bosses and a final boss. Your main way of getting around is a spinning wheel with spikes on it. You also have an assortmenet of weapons like machine guns, RPGs, shotgun, etc. You can customise your characters look and wheel, these customisations are just cosmetic but they're humourous.

The story of the game is also quite entertaining where Ash(protagonist) has pictures taken of him in the bath and called out as being a ♥♥♥♥♥ so he goes on a search for said pictures. The soundtrack on the game works well with the game and further immerses you into the game, where each world has its own track in place.

There are some negatives and they're that the game even at 5-6 hours does slightly drag some of the monsters you have to kill maybe could of been removed. When you kill main monsters(mini bosses) you have a little mini game with a death animation. There are only a certain amount of death animations and mini games and where the mini games don't get annoying the kill scenes do and they break immersion from the game itself.

Overall though the game is enjoyable its worth a look for a couple of pounds/euros/dollars but there are better action/platformers on the market.

(This game has been suggested by Vallinek and given courtesy of..... wait.... SEGA?!)

HELL YEAH to HELL YEAH!!!   KILL KILL KILL!!!!!  A great indie game developed by Arkedo and published by SEGA.   Wait....does this make this indie or third party? ..... Both?  Well, alright then.~

Play as Ash, a mixture between Jumpy the Rabbit King from the cartoon Hero 108 and Laharl from Disgaea, who acts as the new ruler of Hell after his father mysteriously passes away (no, you won't find out why and the plot doesn't go that deep).  Ash rules hell with an iron paw...until one day, someone snapped photos of him f*cking a rubber ducky in a bathtub and posted them on the Internet.  Ash sees this and is infuriated to find 100 views on the article.  To quell his vengeance, he must kill 100 denizens of Hell.   Did they see the pictures?  Are they innocent?  Who cares?!  100 souls will quell his anger.  One for each view of that article.

With your primary weapon as a giant buzz-saw blade equiped with guns, rockets, grenades, lasers, etc., you can't really go wrong with killing.   Every finishing move is a mandatory minigame that often leads to a brutal demise of your victims.  Ash really is one ruthless rabbit who doesn't give a f*ck.

PROS:
Tons of ways to slaughter
Great humor
Memes here and there (spot them all)
Easy to pick up and play
Achievements  (easy 100%)

CONS:
Not worth full price ($15)
Obligatory jackpot achievement
Too short
No achievements for doing more than 10 side-missions
Some obligatory minigames can either be too easy or too repetitive (if you liked WarioWare type games, then you may enjoy it)
Ending song loops 5-6 times after you beat the game...gets annoying
Only one save file
Very limited replayability (you beat the game, you can roam around, play slots or complete challenges...or DLC challenges, but that's about it. Aside from that, the only thing you can do is reset your file to get additional gameplay.)


I grew up with Nintendo.  I'm starting to like SEGA more nowadays.  This game isn't worth full-price, but it is worth playing if you find it on sale.  Thank you, SEGA, you done good.  ^_^

So, do I recommend this game?  Hmm....what was the name of this game again?   Oh yeah.....HELL YEAH!

One of the most fun games I've ever played. It has its flaws, I'll get to that, but it has so many killer merits that it is just a pure pleasure to look at and especially to play. How a great game like this gets a 64 metacritic rating displayed and a truly awful game like house of dead ice skating ninjas gets a 79 displayed is beyond stupid. Metacritic and the dimwit reviewers they combine are all ran by blindfolded monkeys banging on keyboards. This game is easily a 75 or higher. It can get absolutely frustrating at times but with a little effort you will get by. Seems like that's a trend now: try finding a game made in the last 6 years that does not have at least one part that is astronomically frustrating. The game has somewhat loose controls meaning that you will careen into things, fall off a platform when you don't want to, and other minor control issues, but amazingly it isn't that big a deal. Like I said, with practice, every ♥♥♥ is totally kick-able.
One of the most wildly creative games I have ever seen. It has great graphics with everything within a level pleasing to look at. The art direction is some of the best and most creative I've ever seen in a game. I could not ever tire of looking at this game. The real gem of this game is how you kill the main enemies. You go through the game and your goal is to eventually find and kill all 100 special monsters. Once you whittle its life bar down, it shows a screen where you do a brief mini-game to finish him off, ranging from tapping the A button (I'm using a wired xbox 360 controller, a controller is highly advised) to matching up a symbol or answering a question. After that, it shows a really hilarious kill animation. One had me do a little driving mini game where I avoiding things on the road for a little bit with a semi, then the kill on the special monster was a giant semi smashing into it then backing over it about 20 times. Another had a satellite shoot down a kill beam and a NASA control voice counted down from 5 and it destroyed the monster. There are a bunch of different ways and they are all cool to see. But of course there aren't 100 fatalities, one for each boss. No there are much less than that so you will be seeing repeats of fatalities but, for me anyway, they mostly never get old.

House of Dead Ice Skater Ninjas is a pass. Pass it and play this. I am mentioning that game because at the time I had just beat that game right before I started playing this one. This game is a lot of crazy fun so you can forget garbage indie games like that. Loving every minute of this game. Besides this games (minor) flaws, I can overlook them because of how wildly fun it is and how intelligently creative the whole thing is.

Such good work done here, 8/10

A weird side-scrolling game where the main point is to kill 100 monsters that may or may not have inappropriate pictures of your character.  The basic loop involves navigation in a metroidvania-looking world, running across mini-boss sort of monsters and killing them.  This involves shooting them until they get to no health and then successfully completing what can only be described as (one of many) warioware-style minigames.  There are some larger bosses, but only a few.

PROS:
- Navigation is fun and varied. The levels are navigated by means of vehicles sections and on foot.
- Good art style.
- Not too crazy difficult.

CONS:
- The game sometimes tries a bit too hard to be funny or edgy.
- Might feel a bit redundant.

If you've ever played Jazz Jackrabbit (if you haven't go play it now) you'll immediately see the resemblence, and you'll be reminded of a game Epic would have made had they had the resources modern day game creators do.  It has snappy load times, great optimization, a *huge* amount of customizable hats and skins for your character to unlock and find, and lots of weapons at your disposal to destroy your enemies with.

In Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit you play as the prince of hell, who was photographed secretly by paparazzi while bathing, now you go on a quest to find all 100 monsters in hell who have seen your nudes and exact revenge. After defeating each monster to finish it off you are brought into a variety of WarioWare type minigames to get that final hit. if you fail the boss heals a little and you have to do it again. While not complex the finishers were pretty fun, in my opinion.

The game has a lot of stuff in it to do, you've got customizations to collect, weapons to purchase, and even an island where you keep your monster friends who do jobs for you (slave labor). There are even side missions you can complete for extra rewards. While the game is not very long if oyu rush through it, it can be quite substantial if you try to collect everything and 100 percent it.

I recommend Hell Yea! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit to fans of platformers, adventure games, sidescroling shooters, and anyone who just likes and indie game with cheesy comedy.

A cartoony metroidvania-esque game.
Its gameplay consists of the typical shootyshoot and platforming like many other metroidvania titles have although it's incredibly underwhelming in the metroidvania area since there is very little reason to go back to anything aside from the few points when you have to near the end of the game. There are some cosmetic gifts you can try to find and some simple side missions but they're not very rewarding themselves.

Playing with both a KB+M and a controller are both doable. During some segments though it's far more ideal to use the mouse for the faster aiming since for some reason using the right analog stick for these particular sections is incredibly slow whilst the mouse is as fast as you move it.

This game likes to emphasize about its loads of violence & gore but it's hard to take seriously since the entire game's animations look like something I'd see in a mobile game. With its groan-inducing humor and cartoony artstyle though I guess it shouldn't entirely be taken so.

The main goal throughout the game is just to platform your way through extremely standard maps to find and kill special monsters so you can unlock doors where you're to platform and kill more monsters so you can unlock more doors to do the same thing and eventually fight a boss, which itself is a part of the special monster pool. The special monsters are basically the keys to unlock doors when they're dead and for most of them it's an incredibly tedious process since the method for taking them down are usually either shoot them down or grind them down with your sawblade. Afterwards, as their HP reaches 0, you have to go through this Warioware-like minigame each time. If you fail the minigame you take loads of damage and they remain alive so you'd have to hit 'em a small bit again to get their HP down enough and do the minigame again where upon actual victory, you'll be treated to an unskippable slideshow-esque Adobe-Flash-like cutscene of a kill. Because there are loads of these special monsters in the game you'll encounter the same minigame and cutscene again and again, so even if you're a fan of the eye-rolling humor in the game they'll lose their appeal. As I got bored of seeing the minigame's reused cutscenes I tried alt+tabbing to another window for a bit and apparently it pauses the entire game sort of so the cutscene itself would just hang there until I went back to the game where it'd finally continue the little slideshow.
While much of these monsters are tedious to kill there are quite a few that get pretty clever in terms of finding the method of killing special monsters but these mostly appear at the later half of the game. At these times the game turns into a puzzle platformer sort of.

Nearly all weapons have unlimited ammo as they constantly recharge themselves. I never found myself using all of them since I didn't particularly need more than but a few.
If you're using a controller, trying to use the sawblade and a gun can get confusing. By default you press RT to drill with the sawblade but to shoot your guns you have to aim with the right analog stick and then press RT. I found myself drilling accidentally when I should shoot too many times.
For some wad of a reason anything that's even mostly off-screen is invincible. You can shoot in their direction but if you can't see them you can't hurt them no matter how big of a target they are. This becomes a serious problem against enemies that require you to move a lot to evade anything that'd hurt you. It's as if your fired projectiles disappear from the game as soon as they leave the screen.

Checkpoints aren't the best and are made a little worse plenty of times when they're right before a cutscene of sorts where characters speak. Each time you die at these times you'll have to go through the cutscene over and over again. You can't skip these dialogue things entirely so all you can do is mash NEXT until it's all over each time in case you'd rather not go through all that again, and even that's still slow.

It's a simple game overall with humor for the lowest common denominator but I definitely don't think it's $15 worth for little content.

reviewText:
While the game has some strong visuals and music, it is let down by the gameplay, controls and level design.

The controls are fairly loose, as you'll easily find yourself running into insta-kill spikes or slipping off platforms. Even basic wall-jumping can misfire, launching yourself off stairs back into the very thing you were trying to avoid.

Dialogue cutscenes are slow and unskippable, even after seeing them a second time (usually after dying to the same boss).

While normal movement is fast, the game is regularly broken up by cutscenes and minigames. The minigames are the sole method for finishing off every boss.

reviewText: Never before have I played a game where the quality differed so drastically from the demo to the final game. About a year ago I played the demo for Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit. I thought that it was simply mediocre. The final game is a complete mess. Level design is incredibly odd. Platforms just seem to be strewn randomly all over the game with no thought put into their locations, making the areas incredibly awkward to travel through and the slippery controls don't help. I was constantly falling off of platforms, often landing on top of enemies or instant death spikes. Navigation only got worse once I got the wall jump. Most of the time when I tried getting onto a platform, I would brush up against the edge of it and the wall jump would launch me to the side, usually into enemies or instant death spikes. The visuals are incredibly drab consisting of red, red, and more red. There might be some blue or purple put in every now and then, but it doesn't make the visuals any more interesting. The music is always either utter garbage or completely forgettable. I wouldn't even classify it as atmospheric, as it never enhanced any of the areas. The dialogue is just awful. Characters are given little to no personality, the jokes are never funny, and are often pointless, and the set up for the story is just stupid. Photos of the Prince with rubber duckies have surfaced on the Internet and 100 monsters have seen them, so the Prince has to go kill them. Who thought that was a good idea? The rest of the dialogue is just an overused joke about the Prince being naked because he's just bones. Overall, I would not recommend this game. It's a boring, horribly designed mess that doesn't deserve your time or money.

The game has decent ideas about killing, but that's it. The cutscenes for killing monsters are cartoonish and enjoyable at first, but gets repetetive after a while.

Colourful candy graphics.

Nothing in it has sense, though there are some lame atttempts. Like, when you kill monsters, they appear in your monsterpedia to bring some joy in the game by giving you scraps of information. You control a rabbit full of killing desire, but nothing else. Lousy attempts at comedy are the only ways he can surface anything in the game about himself, and that's it.

There is nothing to complete here whatsoever. Everthing you can get is straightforward along the path, and sidetracking is next to impossible. The weapons in game are uninteresting and you get them in bundles, instead of making it more fresh and funny to gain them (like for instance, take them from a corpse, or a secret compund, or some plot giving event, form the weapon from soemthing). The characters used in game to help rabbit, are episodic and at the end of it dissapear completaly (Nestor, the giant eyeball thing is more of a decoration). Shops are put in rare areas, the last area doesn't even have a shop I'm afraid, making player to relocate himself for whatever reason before the final battle.

The game mechanics are the ones that get the biggest blow. Using the pad its pretty much impossible jump and shoot anything due to lack of thumbs on your hands and index fingers. Enemies can shoot you from a great distance without problem, whereas when you try to shoot them, even when they're just pixels away from you main view, is impossible. The save system is just damm annoying. Its kind of hard to go anywhere in the game, once someone decides you can respawn with almost 0 HP, granting you eternal pain in the ♥♥♥ of finding any way to replenish your HP, which are scarce (either buy in shop, or find fountain or island).

And speaking of Island, I know its an in-game mini feature that shouldn't bother needlessly... but why does it have meat factory? Its purpose is to give our chap 30HP a bite, replenishing it.  What's the point of giving your character 30HP when you have mx 550HP and enemies hit you for 120 HP a hit? Its like toying with player.

The ending of the game is terrible. Let me just say: the mid fighting long non-skippable dialog is annoying, and the fact that after the final fight there is no after story for ash (did he got back his pictures at least? What about future himself?) leaves player craving for bloodlust. Judging by the game's title Hell Yeah". you'd think people care about grand entrances in game.

All in all everything seems like a bad case of Castlevania clone.

Pro's:

+  candy graphic
+- many weapons... repetitive design and bundle gift
+- killing minigames!... which after a while get boring and you wish they were not there

- non-skippable cutscenes
- quirky controls
- save games that wants you to spend eternity dying looking for save spot
- childish brutality mixed with childish humour = bad taste
- most anticlimatic video game end ever

reviewText:
Hell Yeah! is a game about the prince of hell, trying to discover who took a picture of him playing with a rubber ducky while taking a bath. The picture is then sent out and 100 monsters have seen it. Your goal is simple. Figure out who took your pictures, and make your minions pay. You do this by jumping around and slaughtering said minions of hell using both your giant wheel of death, and a wide range of weapons, like Bazookas, Miniguns, and Grenades.

Hell Yeah! is a game full of charm, and every main monster you slaughter is greeted with a fun mini-game that upon completion gives you an insanely well crafted animation of you destroying the monster, ranging from the Invaders shooting rainbows at it, to a satellite shooting a laser down from space to obliterate the creature. A lot of the charm also comes from the great writing, which also teases some of the cliches that come with a platformer, as well as the fact that the game never takes itself seriously.

The level designs all feel varied, and the game also introduces tons of little mechanics that give you a sense of variety beyond just jumping and running, such as jumping into a cannon to shoot yourself around the level. The minions you kill are also varied in style and attack. Some enemies will require you to just go up and attack, taking them out quickly and efficiently. Some may require you to solve a small puzzle or discover some element of the stage that can interact with them, possibly harming them in the process. Through it all, fighting these enemies never feels like a chore due to the large amount of killing animations, and varied ways the game requires these enemies to be taken out.

The game also features several bosses, while the bosses so far have hearkened back to a normal playing style, they don't feel boring or out of place. They're all varied in mechanics and provide more humor as the main character and the boss banter a little before combat is initiated.

Hell Yeah! is a well crafted metroidvania style action-adventure platformer filled to the brim with great humor, and comical gore that's perfect for anyone. The achievements are also easy and great for any Achievement Hunter (or player) who wants a break from a serious game to net a quick 100%

If I had anything negative to say about the game, it would be about its length. It only took me 8 hours to beat and collect all of the achievements. The length of the game is slightly alleviated by having hats and wheel skins for you to collect, as well as the Virtual Rabbits DLC which is supposed to provide a few more hours of entertainment; however, these don't completely shift the weight off the games length, but it does at least provide some replayability.

Overall, I'd give the game an 8/10.

reviewText:
Hell Yeah! is a Metroid-vania action platformer with a brilliant art-style and an outrageous presentation and story. You play the rabbit Ash, the Prince of Darkness. Your mission is to find 100 zany monster in the depth of hell to recover incriminating pictures of yourself. The story is completley bizarre and thematically fits the game well.
The whole thing plays like a comic book come to life and the art is the main selling feature by far. Cartoonish violence and gore abound as you travel different parts of Hell, each weirder than the next. It works well.

Unfortunately Hell Yeah! suffers a number of suicidal gameplay choices that kill the fun, especially as you progress into the game. Tragically most of these are extremely easy to fix if the developers had the inclination to do so.

Platforming in this game simply doesn't feel right. it feels incredibly 'floaty', as if the force of gravity changes throughout your jump. Imagine jumping against a low ceiling. Instead of your character immediately falling upon contacting the roof, it just hangs in the air and lands at the same time it would have if jumping in open air. This can lead to imprecision and frustrating deaths.
For a game that requires a lot of shooting, the inability to jump, shoot, and aim easily on a controller is utterly unforgiveable. Here are the key binds: R trigger shoots, A jumps, and R-stick aims. Just try it right now, grab your controller and try jumping with A and aiming at something with the R stick. Your thumb effectively needs to use the R stick and push A at the same time. The easiest way around this is to simply allow the player to rebind jump to one of the shoulder buttons, but the game does not allow any rebinds of controller keys. I had to play the game half with a controller for platforming sections, and half the game with a keyboard for combat. No reason this should be the case.
As mentioned, you have to kill 100 unique monsters throughout the game. While these are a highlight, they all must be finished off Mortal Kombat style. After depleting its health bar the old fashioned way, a Wario-ware style minigame pops up that you must win. Fail, and the monster revives and you take damage. While the finishers add to the overall game, the need for what is a complicated and even punishing QTE is not. There are some mini-games that are far harder than the monsters themselves (looking at your Hide and Seek).
I have other less important critcisms. New weapons aren't unique enough, difficulty progression isn't really there with regards to combat, and an entire side-game called Monster Island feels wholly unnecessary. But its the above 3 criticisms that truly hamper the game and it cannot be recommended as is.

This game is not as much terrible as it is mediocre. It was amusing at first, rolling around and shooting at anything that moved. And the fatality-like kills that resulted from defeating each boss were amusing at first ...

... and then repetition set in, more or less at the 30 minute mark. There's not much variety to the platforming. The colors are obnoxious. There's not a lot of variety to how to beat the bosses. And the fatalities are recycled later.

Again, it's not bad. It's just boring. The map is helpful to understand where you are and where enemies are. The gamepad layout is fairly intuitive. The controls are reasonably responsive. Technically, it's okay. But it's painful to play after a while because it's so dull.

Also, don't bother spending time with the Island, which is simple prison labor management system using the enemies you've defeated to generate more money. I barely touched this and still had plenty of money to buy EVERYTHING in the game.

Really, I only finished the game so that I can delete it without regrets and never think to play it again.

I also had one of the DLCs, Virtual Rabbit Missions, installed. Don't bother with it. They're lame timed missions, like race to the end within the time limit or kill all enemies within the time limit. I think each mission is about 30 seconds, so it's really not worth the money.

I'd probably give it a 3/10. Seriously, this game was so dull that I had to play it in small doses because it gave me headaches from the sheer boredom.

reviewText:
Well, this game started off feeling very low-budget and not in the good way, but that was the high point of my experience with it. The platforming is mediocre at best. Half of the time, it can be difficult to see what exactly is dangerous and what isn't, something that's immediately obvious from the first level where you, the so-called Prince of Hell, walk through flames without harm, except for those ones, which look virtually identical, especially in Hell which is composed of fire. Those flames will damage you, except for the ones that don't, got that? The story seems to start halfway through, like I missed a few levels or something, but no, it's just bad writing, the one consistent thing throughout the entire game. The jokes barely raised more than a weak smile at their best, which is rare. Landing a jump can be about as pixel perfect at times as Super Meat Boy, which would be okay a) you didn't slide everywhere like the ground was made of ice and b) if the levels weren't cluttered with useless junk as, unlike SMB's clean visuals, the cartoonish graphics throw everything but the kitchen sink into the background, foreground, every ledge, every trap.

Speaking of SMB, let's talk about respawning. How fast could you respawn in SMB? Instantly. Do you know why? Because a game in which you die that amount would get infinitely frustrating if you had to wait even a second to keep playing. Now, Hell Yeah is a game in which you can be stunlocked and die in just a few seconds as punishment for missing one of those pixel perfect landings or making a small error with it's clunky feeling controls. How long does it take to respawn? Well, the boss that made me just quit the game killed me in a method that took about five seconds before I actually died (I can't move or do anything during this period of time), another second or two for the death screen, another three seconds to respawn and then made me rewatch the boss's unskippable introduction cutscene. This happens every time. And because of the previous platforming issues, I have died quite a number of times on this boss.

A previous boss required me to kill it with its own trap. Except how you do that is such a screwup of game design, I actually went into the next area searching for a way to kill it, killed an entirely different boss which was so painfully simple (make it run into a wall) and then had to go back to kill the first one. The way back was guarded by spotlights which signalled another unavoidable, stupidly long death. They were easy to avoid on the way down, but the way back up was hampered by the awful controls and the fact that these spotlights haven't even got any form of pattern to them. One of them literally stopped and zigzagged across the tiny platform I needed to get to for over half a minute. When it got off, I immediately jumped up, only to find the spotlight suddenly rush back to see me and I die. Again. And respawn at the bottom. Again. When I finally got back to the boss, I found how you were meant to kill it and immediately found another checkpoint (the one thing this game mostly gets right) so I didn't have to climb up the tower of doom again. I jump up to the trap to set it off and have it track me to target the boss. I mess up, die, that's fine, my bad. I start again, jump up... and immediately die to the trap because, for no reason whatsoever, it's set up in a different way this time. It pointed in a random direction every time I respawned, half of which were instant death because of the stunlock meaning I get thrown immediately into another source of heavy damage.

The writing is boring, with no reason for anything other than your Facebook pictures got leaked or something, I feel like all of my motive was in a prequel game to this (if there is one, I'm not actually aware of it). The jokes lack any punchline half the time beyond lol

reviewText:
I've owned this since release, and just this moment got around to finishing it.

At it's core it's a fun little platformer with solid 2D graphics , but the deeper into the rabbit hole you go the more tedious it becomes.

In the latter half of the game instakill spikes litter the walls, ground and ceiling.  Checkpoints and healthstations can be painfully far apart, and the only real reward you get for murdering bosses is opening gates to go do more of it.  The quick time events you must complete in order to kill a boss after you widdle their health down can range from simple to mind numbingly aggravating.  Sometimes you'll fight a boss till you're near death only for the quicktime event to be a demanding one you've never seen before, usually ending in you failing and having to start the battle over again from the last level checkpoint.

For the most part the only reason to collect currency is to buy costumes, as most of the weapons are unlocked with story progression.

Had this actually come down in price over the 2 1/2 years since it's release I'd recommend it, but to this day apart from the odd sale it sits on the store glaring at customers for not wanting to shell out $15 for some hit and miss gameplay.

At the end of the day the tedium of the latter half of the game prevents me from recommending it for anything other than a $5 sale.

This is a platformer with a sense of humour, it pokes fun at the publisher (sega) on many occasions. As a platformer it's pretty confident the controls are responsive, sometime to the point of being... Twitchy. Some of the areas or platform puzzles are near rage inducing in either difficulty or just because they don't explain what your doing.
If your a person who dislikes QTE's (quick time events) then I definitely don't recommend this to you. There are 102 boss monsters to kill and the final blow for all of them is a QTE or occasionally a minigame. Failure to perform it causes damage which of course will lead to death on quite a few of them.
There are weapons to unlock and upgrade, plenty of customisation options, some of which are actually requred to progress, thankfully when an item like that is used the nearest shop will stock it for free.

There really isn't much more I can say on the subject of the game really. The story is stupid, but it reveals in that. The combat is pretty solid and the final kills on the bosses generally are entertaining.
If I'm honest I'm not sure I would recommend this at its standard retail value, if it were sale then go for it.

So the Rabbit prince of Hell has been caught in an embarrassing situation with a rubber duck and the only thing that can make it better is vengeance, that and getting the incriminating pictures back and showing everyone who’s boss.

This game is many things, crazy, colourful, insane, fun, psychotic, confusing and frustrating. So let’s start off with the story, it’s silly and fantastical to the nth degree, I loved it. It’s so off the wall zany that I had a blast with it and the crazy characters both friend and foe. The many worlds of hell are super varied and imaginative from the neon night club to psychedelic dream world I loved every one of them.

One particularly favourite part of mine was the huge amount of fatalities there were when taking down the 100 individually created enemies. They are all unique and die in a huge variety of bloody messy cartoonish ways. The vast arsenal of pure destructive weaponry was also another highlight, not feeling the magnum switch out for the flame thrower or one of a half dozen missile launchers, my favourite is the shotgun a must buy when you play.

Not everything is great though, the controls are very tricky to master and even when you get the hang of them they still mess you up from time to time. The DLC missions on a keyboard or almost impossible and took me a few frustrated hours to complete. The in game dialogue is also much more miss than hit with no laughs at all from me the whole play through. The ingame options are also pretty much non-existent with no audio options or graphic changes of any type present.

That being said this game is a lot of fun and I would recommend giving it a go for a few hours of entertainment. If this is on sale pick it up and try not to think too hard as you splatter demons on mass on your one bunny crusade through hell.
One final note, I know I said it before but play with a gamepad, the keyboard is not good and will lead to a lot of frustration with the precision platforming in some sections and virtual missions.

What a shame.
This is a great concept and visual style, wrapped up in poor gameplay design.

Controls are floaty, making timing puzzles for pushing objects (thankfully rare) and precision platforming (not so rare) a nightmare.
Conversations with boss monsters are unskippable, and will repeat themselves on death. If you happen to be above an instakill spike pit when one triggers, good luck not falling in when you regain control.
Enemies will continue to shoot you during the boss kill animations, meaning it's entirely possible to die while killing one of the monsters and have to repeat the battle.
Instagib traps (spikes, acid-spraying monsters) have a habit of sitting juuuuust outside the camera, meaning many occasions of leaping to your doom with no warning.
Heals are few and far between. Have a clutch situation against a hard-fought boss? Better backtrack through the whole level to heal up, or else you'll be stuck one hit from death every time the following checkpoints load.

It's unfortunate, because the game does have its charm (maybe an over-reliance on flat attempts at zany humour, but charming nonetheless). I wanted to like it, as some really nice work went into designing the 100 bosses (at least visually - gameplay-wise not so much). But in the end, I only got through it out of dogged determination. Just shy of six hours, completed the game with all achievemens, and no desire to return to it.

reviewText:
The prince of hell (a skeleton rabbit with a cape) got photographed together with his rubber duck and is lampooned on the internet for it. The only reasonable reaction — of course — is to kill everyone who has seen those embarrassing pictures.
Developer Arkedo sets Hell Yeah's morbid humourous tone from the very start of the game. What follows is a surprisingly good 2D platformer.

On his journey to kill every single one of the 100 monsters fallen in disgrace, our hero rabbit visits various areas of hell, ranging from a casino to space. The game is packed with comic like brutality; exploding enemies, blood fountains and grotesque finishing moves.
On first sight, Hell Yeah seems like one of those gag games, that aim to be taken with a pinch of salt and don't really try to be good games at core. I'm talking about the likes of Brütal Legend or Goat Simulator; games that wouldn't be enjoyable, if their mechanics were stripped off their context. But after finishing Hell Yeah, I feel like I should give up on that prejudice towards gag games.

Hell Yeah takes typical platformer mechanics, like wall jumps, moving platforms and Donkey Kong Countryesque cannons, and combines them with guns, which can aim in 360 degrees, and a buzz saw. That core mechanic itself is functional — precise jumps were a bit tricky though, because there's next to no acceleration and only one movement speed (the directional input is binary and there is no run button).

Steady variety is what makes the game fun in the end. You can play on gambling machines in the casino. There's a part where you operate a submarine and you can shoot rainbows, that bounce off of walls, somewhere else.
Finishing moves are a source of variety too. The monsters don't have individual moves, but more than 25 different finishers are included in the game. They are occasionally really creative and particularly show of the games polished visuals. All of them start with a short quick-time-event or mini game, making them clearly more interesting than most games finishing moves, but bottom line, they still get old after you see the same animation the third time.

After finishing the game, I was positively surprised how much bang I got for the time invested. Every mechanic and idea is used for a short amount of time and then dropped for something entirely new. Take the rainbow gun I mentioned earlier. You get the gun play three or four different situations with it — which all require the gimmick, that shots bounce off walls — and then you never see it again.
On the other hand, the short innovation cycle leaves no room for any of the mechanics to grow complex, which again, fits the far from serious visual and narrative style of Hell Yeah.
It's a cool game. It cracks the jokes, shows off some crazy ideas and ends before it gets repetitiv. Play this with a friend and a few bottles of beer and I bet you have on or two great evenings.

The prince of hell (a skeleton rabbit with a cape) got photographed together with his rubber duck and is lampooned on the internet for it. The only reasonable reaction — of course — is to kill everyone who has seen those embarrassing pictures.
Developer Arkedo sets Hell Yeah's morbid humourous tone from the very start of the game. What follows is a surprisingly good 2D platformer.

On his journey to kill every single one of the 100 monsters fallen in disgrace, our hero rabbit visits various areas of hell, ranging from a casino to space. The game is packed with comic like brutality; exploding enemies, blood fountains and grotesque finishing moves.
On first sight, Hell Yeah seems like one of those gag games, that aim to be taken with a pinch of salt and don't really try to be good games at core. I'm talking about the likes of Brütal Legend or Goat Simulator; games that wouldn't be enjoyable, if their mechanics were stripped off their context. But after finishing Hell Yeah, I feel like I should give up on that prejudice towards gag games.

Hell Yeah takes typical platformer mechanics, like wall jumps, moving platforms and Donkey Kong Countryesque cannons, and combines them with guns, which can aim in 360 degrees, and a buzz saw. That core mechanic itself is functional — precise jumps were a bit tricky though, because there's next to no acceleration and only one movement speed (the directional input is binary and there is no run button).

Steady variety is what makes the game fun in the end. You can play on gambling machines in the casino. There's a part where you operate a submarine and you can shoot rainbows, that bounce off of walls, somewhere else.
Finishing moves are a source of variety too. The monsters don't have individual moves, but more than 25 different finishers are included in the game. They are occasionally really creative and particularly show of the games polished visuals. All of them start with a short quick-time-event or mini game, making them clearly more interesting than most games finishing moves, but bottom line, they still get old after you see the same animation the third time.

After finishing the game, I was positively surprised how much bang I got for the time invested. Every mechanic and idea is used for a short amount of time and then dropped for something entirely new. Take the rainbow gun I mentioned earlier. You get the gun play three or four different situations with it — which all require the gimmick, that shots bounce off walls — and then you never see it again.
On the other hand, the short innovation cycle leaves no room for any of the mechanics to grow complex, which again, fits the far from serious visual and narrative style of Hell Yeah.
It's a cool game. It cracks the jokes, shows off some crazy ideas and ends before it gets repetitiv. Play this with a friend and a few bottles of beer and I bet you have on or two great evenings.

The controls are very simple, it's a Metroidvania style thing. At the start of the game, you get a cool saw-jetpack thingy and are able to jump higher and drill through walls and kill enemies. You'll eventually get cool stuff like guns and missiles! I prefer you use a controller, preferrably the Xbox One controller, because it's a bit better than using a keyboard and mouse.

You kill a monster by, yes, depleting it's energy. When you deplete the bar, you enter a Wario-Ware style minigame that's really fun to play. You can fail sometimes, y'now. Your health is in the form of energy. You can get it by replenishing it at ''blood stations'' or killing enemies. Then, the cool part comes. You can send them to ''the Island'', where the Monsters you defeated can work labour for you and give you extra blood, money and gear in the main game/

I'm only on Zone 3 in the game so far, but it's shaping up to be a very fun platformer.
